review.title: Universal, Unsupervised (Rule-Based), Uncovered Sentiment Analysis
review.abstract: We present a novel unsupervised approach for multilingual sentiment analysis driven by compositional syntax-based rules. On the one hand, we exploit some of the main advantages of unsupervised algorithms: (1) the interpretability of their output, in contrast with most supervised models, which behave as a black box and (2) their robustness across different corpora and domains. On the other hand, by introducing the concept of compositional operations and exploiting syntactic information in the form of universal dependencies, we tackle one of their main drawbacks: their rigidity on data that are differently structured depending on the language. Experiments show an improvement both over existing unsupervised methods, and over state-of-the-art supervised models when evaluating outside their corpus of origin. The system is freely available.
histories: 19 pages, 5 Tables, 6 Figures. This is the authors version of a work that was accepted for publication in Knowledge-Based Systems

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Semantic composition is a natural process for man when he understands the feeling of an opinion. In the sentence "He is not very handsome, but he has something I really like," people have the ability to conclude that the word "very good," "not" the whole expression "very handsome" and "but" impairs the relevance of "he is not very handsome" and increases the word "he has something I really like." On this basis, a person could justify a positive general mood to this sentence. Our most important contribution is the introduction of the first universal and unattended model for compositional sentiment analysis (SA), which is driven by syntax-1http: / / grupolys.org / software / UUUSA / based rules. sections.text: The Gimpel et al. (2011) system serves as a starting point for performing state-of-the-art universal, unsupervised and syntactic sentiment analysis. Although it was originally intended for English tweets, we have found that it performs well in many other language families (Romance, Slavic, etc.) and rely on the free distribution of the Toutanova and Manning tags (2000) for part-time tagging. Dependency parsers are built with MaltParser (Nivre et al., 2007) and MaltOptimizer (Ballesteros and Nivre, 2012). We have trained a number of taggers and parsers for different languages using the tag universal and dependency sets (Petrov et al., 2011; McDonald et al., 2013). sections.heading: 5 Defining compositional operations
sections.text: In this section, we will show the definition of the most important rules we have used to evaluate our system. In practice, this means examining how syntactical constructions that change the mood of an ex-3http: / / grupolys.org / software / TAGGERS / universal-tagsets / monolingual / 4http: / / www.grupolys.org / software / PARSERS / universal tag-sets / monolingual / pression are presented in the annotation formalism used for the training of the dependency saver, in this case Universal Dependencies. We will use examples that follow these universal guidelines as they are available in more than 40 languages and, as shown in § 6, the same rules can be competitive in different languages.

sections.heading: 5.1 Intensification
sections.text: Intensification amplifies or diminishes the sensation of a word or phrase. Simple cases of this phenomenon can be: "I have huge problems" or "That's a bit disappointing." Traditional lexicon-based methods treat most of these cases with simple heuristics (e.g. amplifying or diminishing the sensation of the word after an amplifier), but ambiguous cases can occur where such lexical heuristics are not enough. For example, "huge" can be a subjective adjective that introduces its own SO (e.g. "The house is huge"), but also an amplifier when it modifies a subjective noun or adjective (e.g. "I have huge problems" in which it makes "problems" more negative). Universal compound operations overcome this problem without the need for any heuristics. A dependence tree already shows the behavior of a word within a sentence thanks to its dependence type, and the role it plays in language.

sections.heading: 5.1.1 ‘But’ clauses
sections.text: Compositional operations can also be defined to deal with more difficult cases, such as clauses introduced by "but," which are considered a special case of intensification by authors such as Brooke et al. (2009) or Vilares et al. (2015a). It is assumed that the main sentence associated with "but" loses its relevance to the reader (e.g. "It is expensive, but I love it"). Figure 3 shows our proposed compositional process for this clause, formally: (weighting β, w, w, but), as we must first process more intensively the local phenomena before solving adversatives that are larger in scope.

sections.heading: 5.2 Negation
sections.text: Negation is one of the most difficult phenomena to deal with in South Africa, as its semantic scope cannot be local (e.g. "I do not plan to make you suffer").Existing unguarded lexical approaches are limited to looking at a section to guess the extent of the negation, so it is likely that they consider terms as part of the scope that should not be negated from a semantic point of view. Dependency types help us determine which nodes should act as negation and which should be their sphere of influence. To make it short, let's just illustrate some relevant negation cases and illuminating examples in Figure 4. sections.heading: 5.3 Irrealis
sections.text: Irrealis refers to linguistic phenomena that are used to refer to non-factual actions, such as conditional, subjunctive, or desirable sentences (e.g., "He would have died if he had not gone to the doctor"). It is a very complex phenomenon to deal with, and systems are usually unable to address this problem, or they simply define rules to ignore sentences that contain a list of unreal stopwords (Taboada et al., 2011). In this study, we do not go into this phenomenon in detail, but only propose a rule that deals with "if" constructions (e.g., "if I die [...]" or "if you are smart [...]," considering that the phrase it contains should be ignored in the final calculation. sections.heading: 5.4 Discussion
sections.text: Figure 5 provides an analysis of our introductory sentence "It is not very handsome, but it has something I really like" and shows how compositional operations accurately grasp semantic composition. It is difficult to measure the scope of our rules and the potential of these universal compositional operations, since it is possible to define operations of any complexity for any number of relevant linguistic phenomena. In this line, Poria et al. (2014) define a series of English sentic patterns to determine how feelings flow from concept to concept in a variety of situations (e.g. complementary relationships, direct nominal objects, relative sentences...) via a dependency tree according to the guidelines of De Marneffe and Manning (2008).

sections.heading: 6 Experimental results
sections.text: We compare our algorithm with existing approaches in three languages: English, Spanish and German. The availability of corpora and other unattended SA systems for English and Spanish allows us a richer comparison than in the case of German, where we only have an ad hoc corpus. We compare our algorithm with respect to two of the most popular and widely used unattended systems: (1) SO-CAL (Taboada et al., 2011), a language-dependent system available for English and Spanish, guided by lexical rules at the morphological level, and (2) SentiStrength, a multilingual system that does not use a PoS tagging or parsing step to perform multilingual analysis, and instead relies on a set of subjectivity lexics, snippet-based rules and the treatment of non-grammatical phenomena (e.g. writing replication), we also take into account the Spanish evaluation system developed for the corpus.

sections.text: For the evaluation, we selected the following standard English corporas: • Taboada and Grieve (2004) corpus: A general domain collection of 400 long reviews (200 positive, 200 negative) about hotels, movies, computer or music ua topics, extracted from epinions.com. • Pang and Lee (2004) corpus: A corpus of 2 000 long movie reviews (1 000 positive, 1 000 negative). • Pang and Lee (2005) corpus: A corpus of short movie reviews (sentences). Specifically, we used the test split used by Socher et al. (2013), removing the neutral as they did the neutral for the binary classification task (total: 1 821 subjective sentences). Socher et al.'s system provides set polarity classification with five possible outputs: very positive, neutral, negative, very negative, very negative.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions and future work
sections.text: In this article, we have described, implemented and evaluated a novel model for universal and unattended sentiment analysis, driven by a set of syntactic rules for semantic composition. Existing unattended approaches are purely lexical, their rules are heavily dependent on the language in question, or they do not consider any kind of natural language processing steps to be able to handle different languages using shallow rules. To overcome these limitations, we introduce, from a theoretical and practical perspective, the concept of compositional operations to arbitrarily define complex semantic relationships between different nodes of a dependency tree. Universal parts of the language tagging and parse dependencies make it possible to create multilingual sentiment analyses of compositional operations that effectively deal with semantic compositions over natural language sentences. The system is not limited to any corpus or language, and can be adapted to any new definition or other.

metadata.abstractText: We present a novel unsupervised approach for multilingual sentiment analysis driven by compositional syntax-based rules. On the one hand, we exploit some of the main advantages of unsupervised algorithms: (1) the interpretability of their output, in contrast with most supervised models, which behave as a black box and (2) their robustness across different corpora and domains. On the other hand, by introducing the concept of compositional operations and exploiting syntactic information in the form of universal dependencies, we tackle one of their main drawbacks: their rigidity on data that are differently structured depending on the language. Experiments show an improvement both over existing unsupervised methods, and over state-of-the-art supervised models when evaluating outside their corpus of origin. The system is freely available1 .
